Comparison with historical facts: The expert compared the claim with historical facts about the opening ceremony of the Golden Gate Bridge in 1937. They mentioned that the bridge had two separate opening days for pedestrians and cars, drawing hundreds of thousands of bridge-crossers.
Evaluation of photographic evidence: The expert analyzed a photograph that was claimed to show pedestrians swarming the Golden Gate Bridge during its 1937 opening ceremony. They determined that the photograph was actually taken in 1987 during the bridge's golden anniversary celebration, based on the caption and lack of contemporaneous accounts.
Examination of event details: The expert provided details about the actual opening days of the Golden Gate Bridge, including the estimated number of people who walked across the bridge on the first opening day and the subsequent day when cars were allowed. This information helped verify the authenticity of the claim.
Verification of historical significance: The expert highlighted the historical significance of the Golden Gate Bridge, mentioning that it was once the longest and tallest suspension bridge in the world and remains one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World. This context adds credibility to the claim and supports the evaluation of the evidence.
